title: R41430
content: Inland waterways, managed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, cover 38 states and handle half of all inland waterway freight. The Corps funds maintenance and construction through appropriations and user fees, with new construction costs shared equally. The Corps pays for studies, operations, and maintenance on the inland waterway system, while new construction costs are shared with the commercial industry. Congress is considering proposals for future financing, as the current fuel tax revenue is insufficient for major expenditures. This shortfall limits new projects and ongoing construction, prompting calls for changes in the financing system. Previous attempts to replace the fuel tax with lock usage fees have been rejected by Congress. The federal government has funded and supported inland waterways for commerce since the early 1800s. Despite advancements in rail and highway transport reducing reliance on waterways, they remain an important part of the nation's transportation system. Recent proposals suggest increasing fuel taxes and federal funding for inland waterway costs. Inland waterways remain a significant part of the nation's transportation mix for many commodities, accounting for 4%-5% of total commercial tonnage shipped annually. They are crucial for transporting bulk goods over long distances, especially for specific commodities like grain, oilseed, coal, petroleum, chemicals, and more.
